pageData.text: This laboratory course is designed to be performed in a non-traditional laboratory setting. Safety precautions must be followed to ensure that the science materials do not cause harm to the student or other members of the household.

Only you, the student, can assess all the potential hazards of your laboratory setting, so it is your responsibility to take the necessary precautions. The primary danger in performing science laboratory exercises in a home setting is that young children or pets may find and want to play with laboratory equipment or materials. Many pets have an acute sense of smell and may be attracted to something in the kit. We cannot stress enough:
Keep all lab equipment, chemicals, cultures, and supplies out of reach and away from children and pets.

The following are general safety rules to follow when performing any science laboratory activity. Follow these general safety rules and the specific safety rules found in the Safety section of each laboratory investigation activity. Your instructor may modify these guidelines in accordance with state and/or federal law.

pageData.desc: How to Use Gateway Lab manuals

pageData.text:
Watch the following video on safety overview:
  • Chemistry
  • Field Work
  • Life Science
  • Physics

pageData.question: Who is responsible for the safety of your non-traditional laboratory setting?

options.text: me, the student
my instructor
my roommates
a parent
my landlord

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Only you, the student, can assess all the potential hazards of your laboratory setting, so it is your responsibility to take the necessary precautions.

pageData.question: Which of the following dangers makes performing science laboratory exercises in a home setting different from working in a traditional laboratory setting?

options.text: The possibility of young children finding laboratory materials.
The possibility of accidentally ingesting chemicals.
The presence of other adults in the room.
The lack of windows in the room.
The possibility of materials accidentally catching fire.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The primary danger in performing science laboratory exercises in a home setting is that young children or pets may find and want to play with laboratory equipment or materials. This is unique to a home setting as children or pets are typically not permitted in traditional laboratory settings.

Many pets have an acute sense of smell and may be attracted to something in the kit.

pageData.text: Wear appropriate attire when performing laboratory activities.

text: Avoid loose or dangling clothing or jewelry that could catch on objects or interfere with the lab investigation.
Wear shoes that fully cover your feet. Do not perform laboratory activities while barefoot or wearing sandals.
Wear clothing that covers your midriff and upper legs.
Pull back and secure long hair.
Even with precautions, accidental contact between chemicals and clothing may occur. Washing your clothing after the completion of laboratory activities is recommended.

pageData.desc: Image showing a scientist wearing correct personal protective equipment
pageData.altText: Image showing a scientist wearing correct personal protective equipment

options.text: The attire is appropriate.
The attire is not appropriate, the shirt sleeves are too short.
The attire is not appropriate, they are wearing socks.
The attire is not appropriate, their hair is too long.
The attire is not appropriate, their shoes are not closed toe.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This person’s attire is appropriate for a laboratory setting. Their hair is pulled back, there is no loose or dangling jewelry, their midriff and legs are covered, and their shoes are closed toe.

  • Wear shoes that fully cover your feet. Do not perform laboratory activities while barefoot or wearing sandals.
  • Wear clothing that covers your midriff and upper legs.

pageData.text: Wearing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is required in college science laboratories and is also required for most distance learning science laboratory activities. Look for the following symbols that indicate which PPE is required for the laboratory activity.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.title: Safety Goggles
text: Wear safety goggles to protect against eye injury. Any time chemicals, preserved or living organisms, glassware, or heat are utilized in a laboratory activity, safety goggles are required.
Under some conditions, safety goggles will begin to fog up. If this occurs, step away from your investigation and wash your hands before cleaning your eyewear.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on safety goggles: Putting on Goggles and Glasses

pageData.title: Gloves
text: Wear chemical-resistant gloves to protect your hands any time chemicals are used or specimens are handled.
Wash your hands before putting gloves on and after removing them.
If punctured or torn, gloves should be disposed of immediately.
To limit contamination, removed gloves should not be reused.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on how to put on and remove gloves: Proper Glove Application

pageData.title: Chemical Apron
text: Wear a chemical-resistant apron to protect your clothing any time chemicals, cultures, or preserved specimens are used.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on how to properly wear an apron: Proper Apron Usage

text: Do not use any part of the laboratory kit as a container for food.
Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during the laboratory activity.
Do not place pencils, pens, labels, fingers, or any other objects in your mouth while performing the laboratory activity.
Avoid touching your face, hair, phone, or any other personal items while wearing gloves.
Keep your work space organized to reduce confusion, chance of error, or chance of spilling.
Put away unneeded notebooks and papers.
Keep cuts or open wounds covered whenever using chemicals or handling specimens.
Never return dispensed chemicals to their original containers or place chemicals in an unmarked container.

When using biological cultures, preserved materials, or living organisms:
  • Wipe off the counter with disinfectant before and after the laboratory activity.
  • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the laboratory activity and at any time that you think your hands may have become contaminated.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on handwashing: Handwashing for Microbiology

pageData.question: Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in contamination during a scientific laboratory activity?

options.text: Victor scratches his face with gloved hands.
Henry covers a paper cut with a bandage before putting on his gloves.
Ashton keeps his work area organized.
Chester uses washed hands to de-fog his safety goggles.
Rex removes his textbooks from the work area before starting the activity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Avoid touching your face, hair, phone, or any other personal items while wearing gloves.

pageData.question: Which of the following scenarios is most likely to result in contamination during a scientific laboratory activity?

options.text: Nori chews on her pencil while performing calculations for the activity.
Muriel washes her hands before and after the activity.
Poppy removes her gloves before pulling hair away from her face.
Arwen uses a bleach solution to wipe down her work area before the activity.
Sam steps away from the work area before getting a drink of water.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Do not place pencils, pens, labels, fingers, or any other objects in your mouth while performing the laboratory activity.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take to prevent contamination during a scientific laboratory activity.
  • Do not use any part of the laboratory kit as a container for food.
  • Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during the laboratory activity.
  • Do not place pencils, pens, labels, fingers, or any other objects in your mouth while performing the laboratory activity.
  • Avoid touching your face, hair, phone, or any other personal items while wearing gloves.
  • Keep your workspace organized to reduce confusion, chance of error, or chance of spilling.
  • Put away unneeded notebooks and papers.
  • Keep cuts or open wounds covered whenever using chemicals or handling specimens.
  • Never return dispensed chemicals to their original containers or place chemicals in an unmarked container.
  • When using biological cultures, preserved materials, or living organisms:
    • Wipe off the counter with disinfectant before and after the laboratory activity.
    • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the laboratory activity and at any time that you think your hands may have become contaminated.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take to prevent contamination during a scientific laboratory activity.
  • Do not use any part of the laboratory kit as a container for food.
  • Do not eat, drink, or chew gum during the laboratory activity.
  • Do not place pencils, pens, labels, fingers, or any other objects in your mouth while performing the laboratory activity.
  • Avoid touching your face, hair, phone, or any other personal items while wearing gloves.
  • Keep your workspace organized to reduce confusion, chance of error, or chance of spilling.
  • Put away unneeded notebooks and papers.
  • Keep cuts or open wounds covered whenever using chemicals or handling specimens.
  • Never return dispensed chemicals to their original containers or place chemicals in an unmarked container.
  • When using biological cultures, preserved materials, or living organisms:
    • Wipe off the counter with disinfectant before and after the laboratory activity.
    • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the laboratory activity and at any time that you think your hands may have become contaminated.

pageData.text: Select a counter or other work surface that will not be damaged by bleach. Using a paper towel, wipe the work surface with surface disinfectant (10% bleach solution) before starting the laboratory activity. Leave the surface damp, and allow it to sit for at least two minutes. Then use a dry paper towel to absorb any remaining disinfectant. Repeat after you have finished the laboratory activity.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Watch the following video on how to disinfect your work surface: Disinfecting a Surface

text:
Make your own surface disinfectant by combining 1 part laundry bleach with 9 parts tap water.
  • Be sure to wear PPE when mixing surface disinfectant.
  • If you have any disinfectant left over at the end of an activity, either dispose of it down the drain with running water, or store it out of direct sunlight in a clearly-labeled plastic container out of the reach of children and pets. (An empty bleach bottle is ideal for storing surface disinfectant.)
  • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the laboratory activity and at any time that you think your hands may have become contaminated. It is important to wash your hands even if you wear gloves for the activity.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on how to prepare surface disinfectant: Making Surface Disinfectant

Note: The skin on your hands supports a rich community of microorganisms. Even washing your hands only reduces the number of microbes; it does not remove them entirely. Such organisms thrive and multiply in the warm, moist environment of gloved skin. This is why you should always wash your hands before putting on gloves and again after removing them.

text: All biological cultures grown in petri dishes or culture tubes should be considered harmful. Keep caps and lids on during incubation.

pageData.desc: image of a microbial culture growing in a petri dish
pageData.altText: image of a microbial culture growing in a petri dish

text: Working alone in a laboratory is strongly discouraged but may be difficult to avoid in a distance learning class. When working alone, keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs.

Identify a “lab bench” where all laboratory activities will be performed. We recommend that your lab bench be located close to a kitchen or bathroom.
  • Clear this area of all food and beverages, including drinking water.
  • Remove extraneous material not required for the laboratory activity.

Many kitchen sinks have a sprayer that can be used as an eye wash. A bathroom shower can also be used as an eye wash and safety shower. Hazardous chemicals have been limited to small volumes to reduce the possibility of needing a safety shower or eye wash.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before starting any laboratory activity.

pageData.desc: A person washing their hands in a sink
pageData.altText: A person washing their hands in a sink

text: When hazardous chemicals are being used, always wear appropriate safety goggles and perform the laboratory activity near a sink sprayer or bathroom shower.

Thoroughly read the entire lab investigation and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting. If there are any questions about the laboratory procedures, contact your instructor.
Assemble all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.

Inspect all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.
  • Check all glassware for chips or cracks. Dispose of any glassware that is cracked, chipped, or damaged.
  • Clean any glassware or lab equipment with soap and water if it appears dirty or previously used.
Set up and perform laboratory activities when children are not present. Be sure to secure animals for their own safety while laboratory activities are performed.
Be prepared to devote your full attention to each laboratory activity. Distractions or interruptions can lead to accidents.
Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate to limit distractions.
Never smoke while performing laboratory activities.
Never perform any laboratory activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

pageData.desc: Erlenmeyer flask with a defect in the glass
pageData.altText: Erlenmeyer flask with a defect in the glass

pageData.question: Which of the following pre-laboratory safety precautions regarding a mobile phone is accurate?

options.text: When working alone, have a phone nearby and someone to call if an accident occurs.
Turn up the ringer volume on your phone so you can hear incoming calls during an activity.
Keep your phone in the work area, even if it will not be used during the activity.
Set up your phone so you can watch a movie while you perform the activity.
Turn your phone off before starting the activity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When working alone, keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs. However, your phone should be set to silent or vibrate to limit distractions during the activity.

pageData.question: Which of the following pre-laboratory safety precautions regarding your lab equipment is accurate?

options.text: Clean any dirty glassware to be used in the activity.
Assemble each equipment item just before it will be used in the activity.
Organize all your lab equipment on your lab bench, even if some items will not be used.
It is okay for children to touch lab equipment before the activity, just not during.
Damaged equipment can be used during the activity if it still functions as intended.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Clean any glassware or lab equipment with soap and water if it appears dirty or previously used. Check all glassware for chips or cracks. Dispose of any glassware that is cracked, chipped, or damaged.

hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take before starting any scientific laboratory activities.
  • Working alone in a laboratory is strongly discouraged but may be difficult to avoid in a distance learning class. When working alone, keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs.
  • Identify a “lab bench” where all laboratory activities will be performed. We recommend that your lab bench be located close to a kitchen or bathroom.
    • Clear this area of all food and beverages, including drinking water.
    • Remove extraneous material not required for the laboratory activity.
  • Many kitchen sinks have a sprayer that can be used as an eye wash. A bathroom shower can also be used as an eye wash and safety shower. Hazardous chemicals have been limited to small volumes to reduce the possibility of needing a safety shower or eye wash.
  • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before starting any laboratory activity.
  • When hazardous chemicals are being used, always wear appropriate safety goggles and perform the laboratory activity near a sink sprayer or bathroom shower.
  • Thoroughly read the entire lab investigation and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting. If there are any questions about the laboratory procedures, contact your instructor.
  • Assemble all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.
  • Inspect all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.
    • Check all glassware for chips or cracks. Dispose of any glassware that is cracked, chipped, or damaged.
    • Clean any glassware or lab equipment with soap and water if it appears dirty or previously used.
  • Set up and perform laboratory activities when children are not present. Be sure to secure animals for their own safety while laboratory activities are performed.
  • Be prepared to devote your full attention to each laboratory activity. Distractions or interruptions can lead to accidents.
  • Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate to limit distractions.
  • Never smoke while performing laboratory activities.
  • Never perform any laboratory activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

    • Clear this area of all food and beverages, including drinking water.
    • Remove extraneous material not required for the laboratory activity.

  • When hazardous chemicals are being used, always wear appropriate safety goggles and perform the laboratory activity near a sink sprayer or bathroom shower.
  • Thoroughly read the entire lab investigation and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting. If there are any questions about the laboratory procedures, contact your instructor.
  • Assemble all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.
  • Inspect all laboratory equipment and materials before the activity.
    • Check all glassware for chips or cracks. Dispose of any glassware that is cracked, chipped, or damaged.
    • Clean any glassware or lab equipment with soap and water if it appears dirty or previously used.
  • Set up and perform laboratory activities when children are not present. Be sure to secure animals for their own safety while laboratory activities are performed.
  • Be prepared to devote your full attention to each laboratory activity. Distractions or interruptions can lead to accidents.
  • Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate to limit distractions.
  • Never smoke while performing laboratory activities.
  • Never perform any laboratory activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

text: Never leave your laboratory experiment unattended. Monitor experiments at all times.

pageData.text: If a spill occurs, most chemicals can be cleaned up immediately using paper towels and then thoroughly rinsing the spill area with water. Paper towels can then be disposed of in the trash. Chemicals requiring other cleanup procedures will be noted in specific investigations. In the event of a spilled microbial culture, cover the spill with paper towels saturated with surface disinfectant and allow to sit for at least 20 minutes before discarding.

text: Never pick up broken glassware with your hands. Use a broom and dustpan to pick up broken glassware. Place glass into an intermediate container before disposing into a garbage can.

If a candle or flame is used during the laboratory activity, the potential for a fire exists. Keep all flammable and combustible materials away from the flame, including paper, books, and paper towels.
Know where your fire extinguisher is if you own one. If you do not own a fire extinguisher, they can be purchased at most home improvement or grocery stores.

Scalpels are used in dissection activities and require special handling and disposal.
  • Never cut toward your hand and fingers holding the specimen.
  • Cut in a downward motion using steady, even pressure.
  • Always use a sharp blade.
  • Do not use a scalpel to cut through a bone or heavy cartilage.

pageData.text: Watch the following video on how to properly use a scalpel: Using a scalpel

pageData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes the safe performance of a scientific laboratory activity?

options.text: Ashley asks her roommate to answer the door while she monitors her experiment.
Bobbie keeps a roll of paper towels on the lab bench while using an open flame.
Carla uses a scalpel to cut toward her hand holding the dissection specimen.
Daniela removes her gloves before using her hands to pick up a broken glass beaker.
Evelyn allows a chemical spill to dry before rinsing the area with water.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Never leave your laboratory experiment unattended. Monitor experiments at all times.

pageData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes the safe performance of a scientific laboratory activity?

options.text: Toby discards a broken glass test tube in a cardboard box which is placed in the trash.
Ryan asks his roommate for the location of a fire extinguisher after causing an accidental fire.
Darryl uses a dull scalpel to perform his dissection activity.
Kevin waits until the activity is completed to clean up a chemical spill.
Wallace leaves his lab materials on his lab bench to go to a doctor’s appointment.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Never pick up broken glassware with your hands. Use a broom and dustpan to pick up broken glassware. Place glass into an intermediate container before disposing into a garbage can.

  • If a spill occurs, most chemicals can be cleaned up immediately using paper towels and then thoroughly rinsing the spill area with water. Paper towels can then be disposed of in the trash. Chemicals requiring other cleanup procedures will be noted in specific investigations. In the event of a spilled microbial culture, cover the spill with paper towels saturated with surface disinfectant and allow to sit for at least 20 minutes before discarding.
  • Never pick up broken glassware with your hands. Use a broom and dustpan to pick up broken glassware. Place glass into an intermediate container before disposing into a garbage can.
  • If a candle or flame is used during the laboratory activity, the potential for a fire exists. Keep all flammable and combustible materials away from the flame, including paper, books, and paper towels.

    • Never cut toward your hand and fingers holding the specimen.
    • Cut in a downward motion using steady, even pressure.
    • Always use a sharp blade.
    • Do not use a scalpel to cut through a bone or heavy cartilage.

hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take while performing scientific laboratory activities.
  • Never leave your laboratory experiment unattended. Monitor experiments at all times.
  • If a spill occurs, most chemicals can be cleaned up immediately using paper towels and then thoroughly rinsing the spill area with water. Paper towels can then be disposed of in the trash. Chemicals requiring other cleanup procedures will be noted in specific investigations. In the event of a spilled microbial culture, cover the spill with paper towels saturated with surface disinfectant and allow to sit for at least 20 minutes before discarding.
  • Never pick up broken glassware with your hands. Use a broom and dustpan to pick up broken glassware. Place glass into an intermediate container before disposing into a garbage can.
  • If a candle or flame is used during the laboratory activity, the potential for a fire exists. Keep all flammable and combustible materials away from the flame, including paper, books, and paper towels.
  • Know where your fire extinguisher is if you own one. If you do not own a fire extinguisher, they can be purchased at most home improvement or grocery stores.
  • Scalpels are used in dissection activities and require special handling and disposal.
    • Never cut toward your hand and fingers holding the specimen.

text: Each laboratory activity will have specific instructions for safe disposal of every culture and/or chemical.
Disinfect your lab bench with surface disinfectant before beginning work. Your laboratory manual may also instruct you to disinfect other items, such as the culture tube rack and grease pencil.

Most investigations will require you to use inoculating tools (inoculating loops, swabs, cell spreaders, and/or pipettes) in order to transfer living microorganisms from one container to another. These tools must be disinfected before disposal. You will need a small, plastic container designated for laboratory use only. A small (8 oz) empty water or soft drink bottle works well as long as it is never used for water or beverage storage again.
  • Label the container “disposal jar” and fill it about two-thirds full with 70% isopropyl alcohol (sold at drugstores as rubbing alcohol).

pageData.text: Immerse the used tools in the alcohol and let them soak for at least 30 minutes before discarding them in the household trash.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>
Used alcohol can be poured down the drain. Allow the water to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol.

text: Disinfect your lab bench with surface disinfectant after stopping work. Then wash your lab bench with soap and water to remove bleach residue.

When you have finished working with a microbial culture and it is ready for disposal, you will first need to disinfect the cultures in a well-ventilated area. A large disposable food storage container (with lid) works well as long as it is designated for laboratory use only and never used to store food again.
  • Label the container “culture disinfection,” put on your PPE, and add surface disinfectant.
  • Immerse each culture tube or petri dish in the disinfectant, and remove the cap or lid.
  • Allow the cultures to soak at least 24 hours before placing them in an opaque plastic bag and disposing of them in the household trash.

pageData.text: Pour the disinfectant solution carefully down a drain and flush with excess water for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach.
Watch the following video on how to properly disinfect and dispose of cultures and microbiology tools: Disinfection and Disposal

text: Wash all non-disposable laboratory plastic ware with soap and water after the activity.
Place all disposable items in the household trash.
Put all laboratory equipment, materials, and chemicals back into the proper Carolina Distance Learning Kit box for storage.
When finished with the above steps, wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
Store the Carolina Distance Learning Kit box out of reach of children and pets when not in use.
Each laboratory activity will have specific instructions for safe disposal of every chemical and/or specimen.
Wash your lab bench with soap and water after the activity.
Wash all non-disposable laboratory plastic ware and pipets with soap and water after the activity.
Put all laboratory equipment, materials, and chemicals back into the proper Carolina Distance Learning Kit box for storage.
When finished with the above steps, wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
Store the Carolina Distance Learning Kit box out of reach of children and pets when not in use.

pageData.desc: image showing past chemical containment methods and modern containers
pageData.altText: image showing past chemical containment methods and modern containers

pageData.question: Which of the following is true regarding laboratory cleanup and disposal?

options.text: Each laboratory activity will have specific cleanup and disposal instructions.
Put all laboratory materials in the refrigerator when not in use.
Discard all used laboratory materials in the garbage can.
Store the kit box containing the laboratory materials on a low shelf when not in use.
Return all laboratory materials to an unmarked cardboard box after each activity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Each laboratory activity will have specific instructions for safe disposal of every chemical and/or specimen.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes how to clean up after a laboratory activity?

options.text: Wash non-disposable plasticware and glassware with soap and water, place all lab materials in the Carolina Distance Learning kit box for storage, and wash the lab bench with soap and water.
Discard all plasticware and glassware in the garbage can, place all lab materials in the refrigerator, and wash the lab bench with a disinfectant.
Wash non-disposable plasticware and glassware with soap and water, place all lab materials in a new cardboard box for storage, and store the kit box on the floor or a low shelf.
Rinse used lab materials with water, wash the lab bench with soap and water, and store the materials on the lab bench.
Wash your hands, wash non-disposable plasticware and glassware with soap and water, and store all lab materials on the lab bench.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Wash non-disposable plasticware and glassware with soap and water, place all lab materials in the Carolina Distance Learning kit box for storage, and wash the lab bench with soap and water. Store the lab kit box out of reach of children and pets when not in use.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take while cleaning up scientific laboratory activities.
  • Each laboratory activity will have specific instructions for safe disposal of every chemical and/or specimen.
  • Wash your lab bench with soap and water after the activity.
  • Wash all non-disposable laboratory plastic ware and pipets with soap and water after the activity.
  • Put all laboratory equipment, materials, and chemicals back into the proper Carolina Distance Learning Kit box for storage.
  • When finished with the above steps, wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
  • Store the Carolina Distance Learning Kit box out of reach of children and pets when not in use.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Review the precautions one should take while cleaning up scientific laboratory activities.
  • Each laboratory activity will have specific instructions for safe disposal of every chemical and/or specimen.
  • Wash your lab bench with soap and water after the activity.
  • Wash all non-disposable laboratory plastic ware and pipets with soap and water after the activity.
  • Put all laboratory equipment, materials, and chemicals back into the proper Carolina Distance Learning Kit box for storage.
  • When finished with the above steps, wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water.
  • Store the Carolina Distance Learning Kit box out of reach of children and pets when not in use.

text: Lyophilized cultures are living organisms that have been lyophilized (freeze-dried) for preservation. They should be refrigerated on arrival to extend their shelf life. Keep the lyophilized cultures in a sealed, labeled plastic bag out of the reach of children.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

The microorganisms used in our Carolina Distance Learning investigations were selected because they pose low risk to students. However, improper handling may still result in infection.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>

Store reactivated cultures in a draft-free, room-temperature area out of reach of children and pets. Cultures in tubes should be stored upright in a tube rack. Cultures in petri dishes should be stored inverted (upside-down). Each culture should be clearly labeled with the scientific name of the organism and the date the culture was started.

pageData.text: If a microbial culture splashes into your eyes, immediately rinse your eyes with water for at least 15 minutes. A kitchen sink sprayer or bathroom shower can be used as an eye wash. Then seek a medical professional for additional advice and treatment.

text: If a microbial culture splashes onto your skin, wipe it off with a paper towel saturated with 70% isopropyl alcohol. Then wash the area thoroughly with soap and water.

pageData.desc: image of nutrient agar plates in a stack
pageData.altText: image of nutrient agar plates in a stack

text: Read and understand all labels on chemicals or biological specimens.

If you have any questions or concerns, refer to the Safety Data Sheets (SDS) available at www.carolina.com.
  • The SDS lists the dangers, storage requirements, exposure, treatment, and disposal instructions for each chemical.

Special Hazards: Most distance learning laboratory activities are designed to avoid use of dangerous and hazardous chemicals. However, some activities require these chemicals and thus necessitate additional safety precautions. These special precautions will be identified using standard pictograms that identify physical and chemical hazards on SDS and labels.

pageData.text: Flammable materials. These usually include alcohol or other flammable solvents. Wear safety eye wear, chemical-resistant gloves, and a chemical-resistant apron. Keep all ignition sources such as flames, pilot lights, or heat sources away from the location of the chemical. Keep the lid on the flammable liquid bottle at all times to reduce fumes and spills.

Corrosive materials. These usually include acids or bases. Wear safety goggles, chemical-resistant gloves, and a chemical-resistant apron. Use these materials near running water that can also serve as a safety eye wash or shower if any corrosive material makes contact with your skin or eyes.

Warnings. These usually include skin, eye, or respiratory tract irritants or substances that exert acute toxicity. Wear safety goggles, chemical-resistant gloves, and a chemical-resistant apron. Use these materials in a well-ventilated area, such as a room with open windows, a garage, or a bathroom or kitchen with an external vent fan.
Environmental Hazards. These are exceedingly rare, and typically include chemicals that are harmful to the environment if released in quantities much larger than those available in your kit.
Health Hazards. These are chemicals that have been shown to have a chance of posing long term health risks. Typically any risk is associated with chronic exposure.

Toxicity. These are chemicals that are known to be toxic if consumed, inhaled or absorbed through the skin. Chemicals provided may have toxicity if consumed in large quantities but not with the amount provided in the kit.

text: Consult your physician if you are pregnant, allergic to chemicals, or have other medical conditions that may require additional protective measures.
Always wear safety goggles, gloves, and apron when handling chemicals.
Always put lids back onto chemical bottles immediately after use.
Never ingest or taste chemicals. If this occurs, seek immediate help. Call Poison Control at 800‐222‐1222 or dial 911.
Never use any chemical in the laboratory kit for any purpose other than the laboratory activity.
Household materials supplied by Carolina Biological Supply Company (e.g., sugar, salt, Alka-Seltzer®, or Kool-Aid®) are not packaged for human consumption and should be considered hazardous.

pageData.text: If a chemical splashes into your eyes, immediately rinse your eyes with water for at least 15 minutes. A kitchen sink sprayer or bathroom shower can be used as an eye wash. Then seek a medical professional for additional advice and treatment.
Watch the following video on the importance of goggles: Lab Safety: Why do I have to wear goggles?

pageData.desc: Why Do I Have to Wear Goggles?

pageData.text: If a corrosive chemical splashes onto your skin, immediately wash the area with cool water for at least 15 minutes. Then seek a medical professional for additional advice and treatment. A kitchen sink sprayer or bathroom shower can be used as a safety shower.
Watch the following video on the importance of gloves: Lab Safety: Why do I have to wear gloves?

pageData.desc: Why Do I Have to Wear Gloves?

The material is flammable.
The material is likely a tissue irritant.
The material is a health hazard.
The material is toxic if ingested.

feedbackData.text: This pictogram describes a material that is corrosive.

options.text: The material is likely a tissue irritant.
The material is toxic to the environment.
The material is corrosive.
The material is flammable.
The material is a carcinogen.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This pictogram describes a material that is usually a skin, eye, or respiratory tract irritant or a substance that exerts acute toxicity.

pageData.text: The following are general safety rules to follow when performing any scientific field activity. Follow these general safety rules and the specific safety rules found in the Safety section of each investigational activity.

pageData.title: Pre–Field Work Safety Precautions
text: Make sure you are healthy enough to participate in field work. If you have concerns, consult your physician before engaging in field work.

Prepare a written safety plan. Send a copy of this plan to your instructor, and leave a copy with someone local to your area. The safety plan should include:
  • A person to contact in case of emergency.
  • Locations where you plan to work.
  • Approximate arrival and departure times/dates.
  • Addresses and phone numbers of all participants.
  • Name, address, and phone number of the nearest hospital or medical clinic.
  • A description of the activities to be performed.
  • A list indicating the cell phone carrier for each phone being taken into the field.
  • A list of potential hazards you could encounter, including possible adverse weather conditions. Discuss your plan with your instructor and have them advise you on the hazards particular to your location.
Working alone in the field is strongly discouraged. Take a responsible partner into the field with you. Keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs.
Choose your field locations carefully. Study a map of the area. Cell phone reception/GPS access may be limited or unavailable in the field, so do not rely solely on them.
Monitor weather conditions carefully. Be conscious of the possibility of flash floods, especially when working near bodies of water.

Thoroughly read the entire investigation manual and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting. If there are any questions about the procedures, contact your instructor.

Assemble your safety equipment.
  • First-aid kit
  • Medications, including an epinephrine pen, for emergency treatment of insect-sting allergic reactions, if necessary
  • Sunscreen and insect repellent
  • Flashlight
  • Drinking water
  • Goggles, gloves, and apron (if you will be using any chemicals in the field)
Assemble all field equipment and materials before beginning the activity.
Read Carolina’s Laboratory Safety Guide for information on dealing with any chemicals or reagents you will be using in your field activity.

Inspect all equipment and materials before the activity.
  • Check all glassware for chips or cracks. Dispose of any glassware that is cracked, chipped, or otherwise damaged.
  • Clean any glassware or lab equipment with soap and water if it appears dirty or previously used.
Perform field activities when children and pets are not present.
Be prepared to devote your full attention to each field activity. Distractions or interruptions can lead to accidents.
Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate in order to limit distractions.
Never perform any field activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
Obtain written permission before entering private property.

Most of the activities in your Carolina Distance Learning Kit can be performed in relatively high-traffic areas, such as public parks and nature preserves. If you choose a more remote location or plan to work overnight, consult additional literature on outdoor safety, such as the USDA Forest Service website for outdoor safety (https://www.fs.usda.gov/visit/know-before-you-go/safety).

pageData.desc: photo of many people working in a corn field wearing appropriate clothing for field work
pageData.altText: photo of many people working in a corn field wearing appropriate clothing for field work

pageData.title: Field Attire
text: Wear sensible clothing when performing field activities. Avoid loose or dangling clothing or jewelry.
Wear attire that is appropriate to the climate and the activity.

Be sensible of possible temperature fluctuations and layer your clothing appropriately. Long sleeves and long pants keep both the sun and insects away, but be conscious of the potential for overheating.
A wide-brimmed hat and sunglasses provide good protection from the sun.
Use sunscreen. Sunburn can occur even when it is overcast or in the winter.
If you anticipate working in or around water, wearing a material that dries quickly can be beneficial.
If the water you are working in is potentially contaminated, gloves and either rubber boots or waders are recommended in order to minimize contact with the water.
Wear shoes that fully cover your feet. Do not perform field activities while barefoot or wearing sandals.
Pull back and secure long hair.

pageData.title: Performing the Field Activity
text: Check in regularly with the person you left your field safety plan with.

If you have little or no cell phone service, you may wish to turn off your phone to conserve battery power. However, even if a phone cannot make a call, sometimes enough data can be transmitted for rescue workers to find you in the event you become lost, so turning the phone back on at regular intervals is advised.
Drink plenty of water.
Reapply sunscreen regularly.

pageData.question: Barry is planning to conduct field work as part of his scientific laboratory activity. Which of the following field safety precautions is NOT accurate?

options.text: Keep your mobile phone turned off to limit distractions in the field.
Leave a written safety plan with someone local in your area.
Apply sunscreen and pack plenty of drinking water.
Ask someone to accompany you into the field in case an accident occurs.
Take a first aid kit into the field with you.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate in order to limit distractions. If you have little or no cell phone service, you may wish to turn off your phone to conserve battery power. However, even if a phone cannot make a call, sometimes enough data can be transmitted for rescue workers to find you in the event you become lost, so turning the phone back on at regular intervals is advised.

pageData.question: Sandra is conducting a scientific laboratory activity in the field. Which of the following aspects of her field work set up does NOT conform to safe field work practices?

options.text: She is wearing sandals because the weather is hot.
She is accompanied by her boyfriend.
She plans to return home before a rainstorm is scheduled to reach her field location.
She left her pet dog at home.
She has packed a physical map of her field location.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Wear sensible clothing when performing field activities. Wear shoes that fully cover your feet. Do not perform field activities while barefoot or wearing sandals.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
It is important to know the general safety rules for field work, such as the following.
  • Make sure you are healthy enough to participate in field work. If you have concerns, consult your physician before engaging in field work.
  • Prepare a written safety plan. Send a copy of this plan to your instructor, and leave a copy with someone local to your area. Check in regularly with the person you leave your field safety plan with.
  • Working alone in the field is strongly discouraged. Take a responsible partner into the field with you. Keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs.
  • Choose your field locations carefully. Study a map of the area.
  • Monitor weather conditions carefully. Be conscious of the possibility of flash floods, especially when working near bodies of water.
  • Thoroughly read the entire investigation manual and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting.
  • Take safety equipment with you, which should include items such as PPE, drinking water, any necessary medications, a first aid kit, a flashlight, and sunscreen. Apply sunscreen regularly and drink plenty of water during the activity.
  • Perform field activities when children and pets are not present.
  • Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate in order to limit distractions.
  • Never perform any field activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
  • Obtain written permission before entering private property.
  • Wear sensible clothing when performing field activities. Wear attire that is appropriate to the climate and the activity.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
It is important to know the general safety rules for field work, such as the following.
  • Make sure you are healthy enough to participate in field work. If you have concerns, consult your physician before engaging in field work.
  • Prepare a written safety plan. Send a copy of this plan to your instructor, and leave a copy with someone local to your area. Check in regularly with the person you leave your field safety plan with.
  • Working alone in the field is strongly discouraged. Take a responsible partner into the field with you. Keep a phone nearby and have someone to call if an accident occurs.
  • Choose your field locations carefully. Study a map of the area.
  • Monitor weather conditions carefully. Be conscious of the possibility of flash floods, especially when working near bodies of water.
  • Thoroughly read the entire investigation manual and become familiar with any specific safety issues or cleanup procedures before starting.
  • Take safety equipment with you, which should include items such as PPE, drinking water, any necessary medications, a first aid kit, a flashlight, and sunscreen. Apply sunscreen regularly and drink plenty of water during the activity.
  • Perform field activities when children and pets are not present.
  • Turn your cell phone to silent or vibrate in order to limit distractions.
  • Never perform any field activity while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
  • Obtain written permission before entering private property.
  • Wear sensible clothing when performing field activities. Wear attire that is appropriate to the climate and the activity.

pageData.title: Safety Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this safety assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate attire for a lab setting?

options.text: Loren is wearing an oversized jacket.
Pablo is wearing a T-shirt and jeans.
Kenny is wearing tennis shoes.
Ivan is wearing eyeglasses.
Harry is wearing his hair in a ponytail.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes an inappropriate use of one’s personal protective equipment (PPE)?

options.text: Rebecca removes her safety goggles during an experiment so she can see better.
Jenny’s lab gloves are torn, so she discards them and puts on a new pair.
Thea washes her hands before putting on her lab gloves.
Yumi puts on her lab apron before starting a dissection assignment.
Nina ties the lab apron behind her back.

assestmentData.question: Brody is conducting a scientific investigation in his residence as part of an online lab course. He accidentally gets a corrosive chemical in his eyes and needs to immediately rinse them to avoid injury. Which of the following best describes how Brody should rinse out his eyes given his home-lab setting?

options.text: He should rinse in his bathroom shower.
He should rinse in a park water fountain.
He should rinse with a wet paper towel.
He should rinse with contact lens solution.
He should rinse with whole milk.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT an accurate description of pre-laboratory safety?

options.text: Assemble equipment items just before they are needed in the lab activity.
Check glassware for cleanliness and damage, such as chips or cracks.
Avoid being under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
Set your mobile phone to vibrate or silent.
Have a fire extinguisher readily available.

assestmentData.question: Meghan stores her Carolina Distance Learning kit on a high shelf in a linen closet between assignments. Which of the following best explains whether this is an appropriate location?

options.text: This is a good location because it is out of reach of children and pets.
This is a good location because it is away from sunlight.
This location is acceptable because there are no kit storage safety concerns.
This is a poor location because it is too high to retrieve without assistance.
This is a poor location because it is not temperature controlled.

assestmentData.question: A chemical that is toxic if consumed, inhaled or absorbed through the skin will be identified in the lab manual by which special hazard pictogram?
Which of the following best describes the method for cleaning up and disposing of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the glass in a hard-sided container for disposal in the household garbage.
Use gloved hands to collect the glass in a hard-sided container for disposal in the household garbage.
Use oven mitts to collect the glass in the household recycling.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the glass in a bag for disposal at an on-campus facility.
Use a vacuum to collect the glass for disposal directly in the household garbage.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to prevent contamination?

options.text: Return dispensed chemicals to their original containers.
Keep the work area organized.
Never use lab containers as food containers.
Refrain from placing objects in your mouth during a lab activity.
Remove chewing gum from your mouth before a lab activity.

pageData.title: Safety Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Safety Assessment.

pageData.title: Safety Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the safety assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

typeBefore.text: All of your Carolina Distance Learning Investigations include a Lab Notebook. Your first assignment will be to familiarize yourself with the Lab Notebook and how to print off a copy to turn into your instructor.

pageData.text: In the upper right-hand corner of this page, click on “Lab Notebook”, and enter your name when prompted.
Read the Lab Safety Contract and electronically sign your name by typing your name and today’s date.
Take a picture of yourself with your Carolina Distance Learning Science Kit or a receipt confirming you purchased the kit. Upload your photo to the Lab Notebook.
The last page of the Lab Notebook is a “Notes” section. This is where you can record a message to your instructor if you choose.
Click on the “print” button that is found below the “Notes” box.  You will be prompted to save your file as a pdf.
Download your file and then turn it in to your instructor.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Refer to this manual throughout the term for best laboratory practices.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to finish your work?

pageData.text: Read through this agreement, then electronically sign the document below.
Students are not permitted to start any Distance Learning Science Investigation without completing the required safety training and signing this agreement.

• I have received the Distance Learning Science Laboratory Safety Manual from the instructor.
  • I have carefully read and understand all of the Distance Learning Science Laboratory Safety Manual provided to me.
  • I agree to carefully read each Distance Learning Science Laboratory Investigation before starting the investigation and will follow all safety precautions as described in the laboratory procedure.
  • I understand I am responsible for following Distance Learning Science Laboratory Safety Manual at all times and the specific safety precautions as described in each laboratory procedure.
  • I understand that failure to follow the Distance Learning Science Laboratory Safety Manual and safety precautions contained in each laboratory investigation could result in a serious accident or injury to myself or others.
  • I am aware that the Carolina Distance Learning Science Kit and the corresponding Carolina Distance Learning Science Investigations may contain hazardous materials which if not stored, handled, or disposed of properly may be hazardous to myself and others that may come in contact with the kit, especially young children and pets.
  • I am aware that the Carolina Distance Learning Science Kit and the corresponding Carolina Distance Learning Science Investigations may contain hazardous materials particularly for students with chronic medical issues or who are pregnant or nursing. I will consult with my physician or health care provider about potential risks associated with the laboratory if I have a medical issue or concern.
Signature
Date

Several investigations in your kit will require you to upload a photo to document your work. Practice uploading a photo now by taking a picture of you with your Carolina Distance Learning Science Kit or a copy of your receipt to prove you purchased the kit.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

On the next page you will see a section where you can record notes to your instructor.  Once you have completed this lab notebook, click on the “print” button to create a pdf.   Download the pdf and turn it in to your instructor.
